docs.title: Networking
docs.text: Core networking concepts and protocols.

docs.title: IPv4 Fundamentals
docs.text: An IP address is a unique identifier assigned to each device connected to a network. A good analogy is a postal address: it helps data reach the correct destination.

docs.title: IPv4 (Internet Protocol version 4)
docs.text:
IPv4 uses a 32-bit address. It is written in dotted-decimal format, made of four numbers separated by dots:

192.168.10.25

Each of the four parts is called an octet because it contains 8 bits. With 8 bits, you can represent 256 values (0–255), so 255 is the largest value possible in one octet.

With 32 bits total, IPv4 provides about 2^32 ≈ 4.3 billion unique addresses.

docs.title: Network and host portions (subnet masks)
docs.text:
An IPv4 address can be thought of as two parts: a network part and a host part. The subnet mask defines where that split happens (for example 255.255.255.0).

This split helps devices and routers determine whether a destination is on the local network or must be reached through routing.

docs.title: Classful addressing (historical background)
docs.text:
In the early days of IPv4, addresses were grouped into fixed “classes” to simplify allocation. This is called classful addressing. It is important historically, but modern networks use classless addressing.

  • Class A: 1.0.0.0 – 126.255.255.255 (default mask 255.0.0.0)
  • Class B: 128.0.0.0 – 191.255.255.255 (default mask 255.255.0.0)
  • Class C: 192.0.0.0 – 223.255.255.255 (default mask 255.255.255.0)
  • Class D: multicast (224.0.0.0 – 239.255.255.255)
  • Class E: experimental/reserved (240.0.0.0 – 255.255.255.255)

With default masks, the maximum hosts per network were typically:

  • Class A: 16,777,214
  • Class B: 65,534
  • Class C: 254

docs.title: Private vs public IPv4
docs.text:
As the internet grew, the IPv4 pool started to run out. To extend IPv4, special ranges were reserved as private IP addresses. Private addresses can be reused across different networks because they only need to be unique inside a local network.

The trade-off is that private IP addresses are not routable on the public internet. For internet access, private addresses typically use NAT (explained below).

Private ranges:

  • 10.0.0.0 – 10.255.255.255
  • 172.16.0.0 – 172.31.255.255
  • 192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255

A public IP address is globally unique and routable on the internet, usually assigned by your ISP.

docs.title: NAT (Network Address Translation)
docs.text:
NAT allows many private devices to share one public IP address. A router translates internal private addresses to a public address when traffic goes out to the internet, and then maps responses back to the correct internal device.

NAT helps conserve public IPv4 addresses and reduces direct exposure of internal addressing, but it does not replace proper firewall rules and security controls.

flowchart LR A["Private IP LAN"] --> B["NAT Router"] B --> C["Public IP Internet"]

docs.title: Subnetting
docs.text: Subnetting is the process of dividing a larger network into smaller networks (subnets). It helps allocate IP addresses efficiently, reduces unnecessary broadcast traffic, improves performance, and supports segmentation for better security and management.

docs.title: Classless addressing: VLSM and CIDR
docs.text:
Classful addressing wasted many IP addresses because it forced fixed network sizes. In modern networks, classless addressing is used, where the subnet mask (prefix length) can be chosen to fit the required number of hosts and subnets.

  • VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Masking): use different subnet sizes within the same overall network.
  • CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing): uses prefix notation like 192.168.10.0/24 for allocation and routing.

docs.title: IPv6 (Internet Protocol version 6)
docs.text:
IPv6 was designed to solve IPv4 exhaustion and improve scalability. IPv6 uses a 128-bit address space, providing an extremely large number of unique addresses (2^128).

IPv6 addresses are written in hexadecimal and separated by colons. Example:

2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334

IPv6 is written as eight groups (often called hextets). Each hextet represents 16 bits and ranges from 0000 to FFFF (where FFFF equals 65,535 in decimal).

docs.title: IPv4 vs IPv6 (summary)
docs.text:
• Address size: IPv4 is 32-bit; IPv6 is 128-bit.
  • Format: IPv4 is dotted-decimal; IPv6 is colon-separated hexadecimal.
  • Address space: IPv6 provides vastly more addresses than IPv4.
  • NAT: common in IPv4; less necessary in IPv6 (though still used in some cases).
  • Operations: IPv6 supports cleaner large-scale allocation and routing.

docs.title: Wrap-up
docs.text: IPv4 is still widely used, but limited. Private addressing and NAT helped IPv4 scale, while IPv6 provides the long-term solution with a huge address space. Many networks run both during the transition (dual-stack).

docs.title: 1. Scope and Context Definition
docs.text:
This step prevents “boiling the ocean” and aligns stakeholders.

Define the boundaries and purpose of the assessment.

  • Assessment objective (why the assessment is being performed)
  • In-scope systems, processes, applications, or assets
  • Explicit out-of-scope items and assumptions
  • Business and operational context (IT, OT, safety, regulatory)

Clearly defining scope avoids scope creep and keeps the assessment focused and actionable. Early engagement with management ensures alignment, ownership, and approval before commencing a significant security initiative.

docs.title: 2. System Characterisation
docs.text:
This step establishes asset value and exposure.

Understand what you are protecting.

  • System architecture, dependencies, and integrations
  • Data flows and trust boundaries
  • Criticality to business operations, production, safety, or compliance
  • Asset owners and key operational stakeholders

This step builds a practical understanding of the environment. High-level system and data flow diagrams are often sufficient and help visualise interactions and exposure points.

docs.title: 3. Threat Identification
docs.text:
Threats describe who or what could cause harm.

Identify credible threat sources and events relevant to the environment.

  • External threats (cybercriminals, nation-state actors, hacktivists)
  • Internal threats (malicious, negligent, or accidental)
  • Environmental or operational threats (power loss, misconfiguration)
  • IT-specific and OT-specific threat scenarios

Threat catalogues can be used as reference points, but should be filtered to include only realistic and applicable threats.

docs.title: 4. Vulnerability Identification & Analysis
docs.text:
Vulnerabilities explain how harm could occur.

Identify weaknesses that threats could exploit.

  • Technical vulnerabilities (software, firmware, network)
  • Configuration weaknesses
  • Process or procedural gaps
  • People and capability gaps

Vulnerabilities may be identified through vulnerability scanning, penetration testing, audits, or operational reviews. The focus is on meaningful weaknesses rather than exhaustive lists of low-risk findings.

docs.title: 5. Control Analysis (Current State)
docs.text:
This step determines the true exposure — not just theoretical risk.

Assess existing controls and their effectiveness.

  • Preventive, detective, and corrective controls
  • Technical, administrative, and physical controls
  • Control coverage, maturity, and known gaps

Controls are typically assessed using an established framework appropriate to the environment. This step often produces a useful by-product in the form of a gap assessment.

docs.title: 6. Likelihood Assessment
docs.text:
This step estimates how probable a threat scenario is.

Estimate the probability of threat exploitation by considering:

  • Threat capability and intent
  • Vulnerability exploitability
  • Effectiveness of existing controls
  • Environmental exposure

Likelihood should be assessed using a consistent and repeatable method, commonly expressed as Low / Medium / High or a numeric scale.

docs.title: 7. Impact Assessment
docs.text:
This step evaluates the consequences if a risk materialises.

Determine the potential impact to the organisation.

  • Safety and human impact
  • Operational disruption
  • Financial loss
  • Regulatory or legal consequences
  • Reputational damage

Impact ratings should reflect worst-credible outcomes, not worst-case speculation.

docs.title: 8. Risk Determination (Inherent and Residual)
docs.text:
This step allows risks to be compared and prioritised.

Calculate and classify the risk level.

  • Inherent Risk: Likelihood × Impact (before controls)
  • Residual Risk: Likelihood × Impact (after controls)
  • Risk ratings aligned to the organisation’s risk matrix

This step enables meaningful comparison across risks and supports prioritisation.

docs.title: 9. Risk Treatment & Recommendations
docs.text:
This step defines how risk will be managed.

Determine how each risk will be handled.

  • Mitigate (improve or implement controls)
  • Accept
  • Transfer
  • Avoid

For each risk, define recommended actions, responsible owners, and the desired target risk state.

docs.title: 10. Documentation, Review & Approval
docs.text:
This step ensures traceability, governance, and repeatability.

  • Document assumptions, analysis, and decisions
  • Obtain stakeholder and risk owner sign-off
  • Define review triggers (e.g. annual, post-change, post-incident)

Risk assessment is not a one-off activity and should be reviewed regularly to remain relevant.

Framework Alignment This risk assessment approach aligns with ISO/IEC 27005 and NIST SP 800-30 and is designed to be applicable across IT, OT, and hybrid environments.

docs.title: Cybersecurity Risk Assessment
docs.text: This article describes a practical 10-step approach to cybersecurity risk assessment. It walks through scoping, understanding the system, identifying threats and vulnerabilities, assessing controls, and evaluating and treating risk. The approach is designed to be easy to follow, repeatable, and suitable for IT, OT, and hybrid environments.

docs.title: 1. Scope and Context Definition
docs.text:
This step prevents “boiling the ocean” and aligns stakeholders.

Define the boundaries and purpose of the assessment.

  • Assessment objective (why the assessment is being performed)
  • In-scope systems, processes, applications, or assets
  • Explicit out-of-scope items and assumptions
  • Business and operational context (IT, OT, safety, regulatory)

Warning

Poorly defined scope is the most common cause of ineffective risk assessments and uncontrolled scope creep.

Note

Early engagement with management helps establish ownership, priorities, and approval before starting a significant security initiative.

docs.title: 2. System Characterisation
docs.text:
This step establishes asset value and exposure.

Understand what you are protecting.

  • System architecture, dependencies, and integrations
  • Data flows and trust boundaries
  • Criticality to business operations, production, safety, or compliance
  • Asset owners and key operational stakeholders

Tip

High-level system and data flow diagrams are usually sufficient and significantly improve shared understanding during workshops and reviews.

docs.title: 3. Threat Identification
docs.text:
This step focuses on who or what could realistically cause harm to the system.

Identify credible threat sources and events relevant to the environment.

  • External threats (cybercriminals, nation-state actors, hacktivists)
  • Internal threats (malicious, negligent, or accidental)
  • Environmental or operational threats (power loss, misconfiguration)
  • IT-specific and OT-specific threat scenarios

Note

Threat catalogues can be used as reference points, but should be filtered to include only realistic and applicable threats.

docs.title: 4. Vulnerability Identification & Analysis
docs.text:
This step focuses on weaknesses in systems, processes, or people that could allow harm to occur.

Identify weaknesses that threats could exploit.

  • Technical vulnerabilities (software, firmware, network)
  • Configuration weaknesses
  • Process or procedural gaps
  • People and capability gaps

Tip

Focus on material weaknesses that meaningfully increase risk rather than compiling exhaustive lists of low-risk findings.

docs.title: 5. Control Analysis (Current State)
docs.text:
This step determines the true exposure — not just theoretical risk.

Assess existing controls and their effectiveness.

  • Preventive, detective, and corrective controls
  • Technical, administrative, and physical controls
  • Control coverage, maturity, and known gaps

Note

This step often produces a valuable by-product in the form of a control gap assessment, which can inform prioritisation and investment decisions.

docs.title: 6. Likelihood Assessment
docs.text:
This step estimates how probable a threat scenario is.

Estimate the probability of threat exploitation by considering:

  • Threat capability and intent
  • Vulnerability exploitability
  • Effectiveness of existing controls
  • Environmental exposure

Tip

Likelihood should be assessed using a consistent and repeatable scale (e.g. Low / Medium / High or numeric) to support comparison across risks.

docs.title: 7. Impact Assessment
docs.text:
This step evaluates the consequences if a risk materialises.

Determine the potential impact to the organisation.

  • Safety and human impact
  • Operational disruption
  • Financial loss
  • Regulatory or legal consequences
  • Reputational damage

Note

Impact ratings should reflect worst-credible outcomes, not worst-case speculation.

docs.title: 8. Risk Determination (Inherent and Residual)
docs.text:
This step allows risks to be compared and prioritised.

Calculate and classify the risk level.

  • Inherent Risk: Likelihood × Impact (before controls)
  • Residual Risk: Likelihood × Impact (after controls)
  • Risk ratings aligned to the organisation’s risk matrix

Tip

Consistent risk scoring enables meaningful prioritisation and executive-level reporting.

docs.title: 9. Risk Treatment & Recommendations
docs.text:
This step defines how risk will be managed.

Determine how each risk will be handled.

  • Mitigate (improve or implement controls)
  • Accept
  • Transfer
  • Avoid

Note

Each treatment decision should clearly identify accountable owners and the intended target risk state.

docs.title: 10. Documentation, Review & Approval
docs.text:
This step ensures traceability, governance, and repeatability.

  • Document assumptions, analysis, and decisions
  • Obtain stakeholder and risk owner sign-off
  • Define review triggers (e.g. annual, post-change, post-incident)

Warning

Risk assessments that are not reviewed regularly can quickly become outdated and misleading.

Framework Alignment This risk assessment approach aligns with ISO/IEC 27005 and NIST SP 800-30 and is designed to be applicable across IT, OT, and hybrid environments.

docs.title: The Questions That Matter
docs.text:
A strong cybersecurity risk assessment helps teams understand what really matters, where real risks exist, and how to prioritise action. It provides clarity around assets, threats, and business impact, guiding practical and meaningful security decisions. The questions below outline the key areas a good risk assessment should address.

  • What assets do we own or rely on that require protection? This includes information, systems, infrastructure, applications, people, and services.

  • Which assets are critical to business operations and objectives? Including assets that support safety, regulatory compliance, revenue generation, reputation, and operational continuity.

  • What threats could realistically affect these assets? Such as cyberattacks, insider threats, system failures, third-party risks, and environmental or operational events.

  • What vulnerabilities exist within our environment? Including technical weaknesses, process gaps, configuration issues, human factors, and governance shortcomings.

  • What risks arise from the combination of threats and vulnerabilities? In other words, how identified threats could exploit vulnerabilities to impact systems or business operations.

  • What would be the business impact if these risks materialised? Considering financial loss, operational disruption, safety impacts, legal or regulatory consequences, and reputational damage.

  • What is the likelihood of each risk occurring? Based on historical data, threat intelligence, exposure, and the effectiveness of existing controls.

  • What controls are currently in place, and how effective are they? Including preventive, detective, and corrective controls across people, process, and technology.

  • What additional controls or risk treatments are required to reduce risk? Options may include risk mitigation, risk transfer, risk avoidance, or formal risk acceptance.

  • How should risks be prioritised for treatment and response? Based on risk ratings, business criticality, and alignment with organizational objectives.

  • What regulatory, legal, or contractual requirements apply to the organization? Including applicable laws, industry regulations, and contractual obligations that influence risk prioritisation and treatment decisions.

  • What is the organization’s risk appetite and tolerance threshold? Defining which risks are acceptable, which require treatment, and which must be escalated to leadership.

  • How will risks be monitored, reviewed, and communicated over time? Ensuring risks remain current, controls remain effective, and stakeholders maintain appropriate visibility.
